div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,593] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1906.

div.head: TINNED MEATS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The question of the importation of American tinned meats into Egypt has aroused considerable intertest in view of the recent terrible revelations as to its ingredients. A few days ago a correspondent wrote suggesting that the Alexandria Municipality should exercise some control, but we understand such duties do not come at present within the purview of the Municipality. Of course such functions are really municipal, but owing to commercial treaties considerable difficulties stand in the way. One step in advance in this direction has already been made, the Government having approved only this week of the temporary measures drawn up by the Municipality for the control of frozen meat imports. At to canned and tinned meats, the Municipality is absolutely powerless to exert any control, and it is much to be regretted that such is the case. It is to be hoped that the Egyptian Government will take up this question, for it is essential that there should be some method of preventing noisome foodstuffs being foisted on the community.

In another column we publish two letters from the Egyptian Agents for Mr. Armour's foodstuffs, but we regret that their assertions cannot be considered to be of a character to satisfy the public, especially in view of the extraordinarily weak defence in Mr. Armour's recently issued book "The Packers and the People." The London newspaper criticism of this book deserves to be read side by side with the letters of Mr. Armour's Egyptian Agents. The "Daily Mail" says :—

On the question of meat-packing Mr. Armour is cunningly silent. It is true that he has much to say of the malice of his "yellow" opponents, of the folly of axe-grinding, of the infamy of those "who do not care to come into the open," but even in the few pages which he does devote "to cleanliness and sanitation," he is content with the vaguest assertion. Though he allows that the "slaughtering of meat animals and converting them into food products is not a parlour business," he is confident of his own and his colleagues' rectitude.
"The sanitary conditions of the yards is now pronounced to be practically perfect," says he. And he pleads for a cessation of criticism on the ground of expediency.

"The period of unwarranted and unintelligent criticism of the packers"--thus he argues--"through which we are now passing directly affects this very large export element in our national prosperity. Every time an American sensation-monger, political agitator, or writer for the 'yellow' periodicals seeks to attract an audience by attacking the packers, he aims a blow at the entire live stock and meat-producing industry of the United States —at every cattleman, hog raiser, and sheep grower, and every person engaged in the meat-producing and meat-distributing business."

Was there ever a more absurd argument advanced than this? We care not a jot how many blows are aimed at the raisers of sheep and pigs. We are determined that pots of poisons shall not be imported into England in order to help the meat-producing industry of the United States. And the remedy of the packers is simple and obvious. They may, if they will, invite a stringent inspection. Had they strengthened the hands of the Government a real measure of reform might already have been passed, and something like confidence restored to the buyers of Europe. But nothing has yet been done to satisfy the moderate and legitimate critics, and if the next balance-sheet of Packingtown shows a deplorable decrease in profits, the fault will be the packers', and the packers' only.

Indeed, nothing is stranger in this controversy than the levity of those who would send their cans of mystery broadcast over the earth. If there are falsehood and exaggeration in the statements of their opponents, surely it would be easy to expose the falsehood and to mitigate the exaggeration. To do this Mr. Armour makes no attempt. He finds it wiser in dithy-rambic strains to hymn the glories of his craft. He represents himself as an Atlas, who bears upon his shoulders the industry of America. If we may believe him, "nothing short of the vast and highly organised packing industry as it stands today, with its immense capital and its immense and constant demand for raw material, could sustain so greet an agricultural business as that of the combined corn-growing and corn feeding industry." And when he reflects on the economic progress made possible by the by-products of meat-packing, his voice quivers with emotion. "It is impossible," he exclaims, "to realise the extent to which this touches every physical element in our everyday life—from making worn-out and barren lands yield bounteous crops to supplying the buttons on our coats."
Such rhetoric as this will not help the cause of the packers. And we can only advise Mr. Armour, in the slang of his own Chicago, to "let go the flying rings, and get back to the green earth"

Poetry (or is it "guff"?) cannot reassure us. The one thing needed to allay the public suspicion is a rigorous and honourable inspection, which can neither be shirked nor evaded. Mr. Armour says that it pays the packer to be honest. That it not enough. Before we will buy the packer's wares again the law of the United States must see to it that the packer is honest whether it pays him or not.
If further proof is needed of what the London Press think of Mr. Armour's publication, we append an extract from the "Morning Post" :

With regard to the "Jungle" revelations Mr. Armour hardly gives himself space for more than direct denials. In his own business "not one atom of any condemned animal or carcass finds its way, directly or indirectly, from any source into any food-product or food-ingredient." It is very difficult for the British public without sworn evidence before them either to accept or to reject this assertion off-hand. But they will certainly not be convinced by any mere assertions either that the self-interest of the packer will compel cleanliness even without inspection, or that there is efficient inspection because a Government inspector is appointed. The British public know by their own experience that though ultimately sound business may prove to be the best business, yet large interim profits may be made, and will be made, by unsound business ; that bad food, bad milk, bad houses may and will be supplied at the expense of the people's health, unless the State takes measures to prevent it by positive regulation. They know also by their own experience that regulation is useless without efficient inspection, and that efficient inspection is very hard to secure. These things the British public know. What they want to know further is this: Why did the American packing firms resist tooth and nail Mr. Roosevelt's recent proposals for making inspection effective? That question is not answered at all by Mr. Armour. Till it is answered satisfactorily the case against the packing firms remains unrefuted.

div.head: Council of Ministers.
div.p: The Council of Ministers will officially remove to Cairo on the 14th prox.

div.head: Prince Line.
div.p: The directors declare a final dividend of 2 1/2 per cent., making 5 per cent, for the year.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The Brindisi Mail vià PortSaid closes at the General Post Office, Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Monday next.

div.head: Arabic Examination
div.p: The next Arabic examination for the Army of Occupation will be held on Monday, 17th inst., at Headquarters, Cairo.

div.head: Death Sentence.
div.p: The Maieh Sanieh has ratified the death sentence passed on Ahmed Gomaa Mensi who had poisoned three of his family.

div.head: Persian Consulate
div.p: The Persian Consul at Alexandria, Mihran Kalfaian Khan, has gone to Europe on leave. During his absence the acting Persian Consul will be Aram Bey Archakian.

div.head: Yemen Coffee.
div.p: A disease which attacks the kernel of the bean, has broken out in the coffee plants of Yemen. Samples of the affected plants have been sent to Constantinople to be analyzed.

div.head: Port Sudan.
div.p: The amount of the credit provided for in the last budget for the creation of Port Sudan was L.E. 210,000, and since then further credits have been granted, bringing the total grant to L.E. 315,000.

div.head: The Shoubra Crime.
div.p: The latest witness is Mr. Hébert, a chemist, who gave information yesterday at the French Consulate. The evidence thus far obtained seems to inculpate not only Paillard junior but his father as well.

div.head: Precocious Criminality.
div.p: From Shoubra Kharfout, Shibin El Kom Markaz, comes news of act of vengeance committed by a youth of fifteen, who for some grudge, strangled his infant stepsister. He has made a full avowal.

div.head: Financial Committee.
div.p: Yesterday's meeting of the Financial Committee, under the presidency of Abani Pasha, discussed the salaries of veterinary professors and other matters, which will form the subject of a report to be submitted to the Council of Ministers.

div.head: A Specie Cargo
div.p: The Peninsular and Oriental Company's steamer Britannia, which is due to arrive at Port Said shortly, has on board the following specie for Bombay : bar silver, £112,000; bar gold, £81,000; coin gold, £9,000. Port Said, bar silver, £1,750.

div.head: Carriage Accident.
div.p: On Wednesday evening an old man 70 was knocked down by a carriage in the Mousky and seriously injured. He was conveyed to the caracol without receiving first aid. This is not the first time that this neglect has happened, says a Cairo contemporary, which draws the attention of the authorities to the fact.

div.head: Beni Suef Municipality.
div.p: The inhabitants of Beni Suef are beginning to regret that they have a Municipality. The tax gatherer is abroad in the streets and is collecting taxes to meet the Municipal expenditure for an industrial school, the S. P. C. A., forty kuttubs, Nile improvements, an agricultural road, a bridge, and great grumbling is the result.

div.head: Turkish Play
div.p: On Monday next the Turkish Comedy and Vaudeville Company of Constantinople will give a final performance at the Alhambra Theatre of Les Amours des Paysannee d'Albanie : a comedy in three acts dealing with the romantic life of Albania. On the following evening an Italian Operetta Company will make its debut with the Geisha.

div.head: Motel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel Ramleh : Mr. and Mrs. L. Cuba and family, Mr. and Mrs. H. Stone. Mr. R. Role, Mr. and Mrs. J Heffis, Mr. James Watson, Mr. and Mrs. E. B. Bird, Dr. W. Zechlin, Mr. and Mrs. Ugo Morpurgo and family, Mr. and Mrs. J. Goldenberg, Mme M. Goldenberg, Mrs. H. Spence, Mr. and Mrs. Shabeen Bey Macarius, Mme Kantzky and family, Mrs. L. Sierra, Mr. L. Ghikas, Mr. Jules Fondor, Mr. H. Kant, Misses Heweth, Miss A. Bill, Mr. and Mrs. G. Halt.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

CAIRO: 1 Sharia Kamel.

The newspapers give the gloomiest picture of the financial situation in the provinces. The peasants and large and small landowners are either unable or unwilling to pay taxes and the local government bodies are impecunious. (Reuter)
The official communiqué, which also provides for the summary trial by court martial and execution of offenders, is welcomed throughout Russia by all except the extremist party.
Meanwhile revolutionary ideas are spreading apace, and gaining the adhesion of the peasants.

At a meeting of the social revolutionaries held after the publication of the Government programme it was resolved to continue the terrorism, aiming at the lives of the highest signatories of the programme. (Reuter)
Mr. Fraser, the correspondent of the "Standard" here, has been arrested and flogged by soldiers. He only escaped death through the intervention of an officer. (Reuter)
Hostilities are practically suspended. It is expected that the insurgents will submit. (R.)

div.head:
FRENCH CHURCH CRISIS.
THE POPE AND BISHOPS

div.p: It is understood that the French Bishops will adopt the policy of passive resistance towards the Separation Law, and continue to celebrate mass in the churches as if nothing had happened, leaving it to the Government to do its worst. (Reuter)

Cardinal Merry del Val has telegraphed to the Archbishop of Paris stating that the bishops' address has afforded the greatest satisfaction to His Holiness who finds therein fresh evidence of the complete adhesion of the French episcopate to the Holy See. (Reuter)
The newspapers announce that the Bishops have decided to maintain religion without associations. (Havas)

div.head:
CURE FOR CONSUMPTION.
THE BEHRING FAILURE.

div.p: Dr. Bernheim describes Dr. Behring's cure for consumption as a complete failure, and declares that the patients experimented upon are worse after the injection. (Reuter)

div.head:
GERMAN MANŒUVRES.
TO CONTINUE NIGHT AND DAY.

div.p: The autumn manœuvres are beginning in Silesis, in the presence of the Emperor, and will be conducted as far as possible under war conditions and be continued night and day until the conclusion. The Duke of Connaught is attending. (Reuter)
The imports of the United Kingdom for the month of August show an increase of £2,031,633 and the exports an increase of £3,974,778. The principal increases were in iron, cotton, and steel. (Reuter)
The South Wales coal strike is terminating. The non-members of the Union are joining the Federation. (Reuter)

div.head:
KAMEL AGAIN!
ADVOCATES A CHRISTIAN ENTENTE.
div.p: The "Temps" publishes a letter from Mostapba Kamel, who denies that he had two languages, one for Europe and one for Egypt, and that he would sacrifice the rights of his country to German policy, adding that he would remain purely Egyptian, and accept all loyal cooperation towards national freedom. He advocates an entente between Islam and Christendom. (Havas)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive is desirous of having a new palace at Cairo built for him near the Nile. His Highness will bring the matter to the notice of the Government on his return from Europe.

div.head: ISLAM AND EDUCATION.
div.p: The following is a summary of the speech delivered by Sheikh Mohamed Shakir, President of the Ulema Board of Alexandria, at the price distribution held on the 6th inst, at Abou el-Abbas College :—

"I hope that in a few years I may introduce to the Mohamedan world a number of young men of whom the Egyptian nation will be proud and who would convince those who think that religious education cannot raise up a nation to prosperty and civilisation, of the enormity of their error. I venture to make such a statement, as I hear the local press calling upon the Egyptians to avail themselves of public instruction. They desire education to spread and to grow more and more, while I desire that education to be based on the Moslem religion, that guides the people along the right way." The examination, of the Talaba were in the Koran, the Hadeeth, Arabic grammar and syntax, literature, logic, arithmetic, geography, and calligraphy.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Yesterday another death from bubonic plague occurred at Suet outside hospital.
A fresh victim of the plague was admitted to the Suez hospital yesterday.

div.head: EGYPTIAN RAILWAY FUEL.
div.p: The average freight paid on coal by the Egyptian State Railways last year was 5s.21. per ton. The fuel issued by the State Ralways during the year consisted of 243,697 metrical tons composed as follows : —
Coal, 239.985, foundry coke, 1,192, gas coke, 392, Newcastle coal, 59, Briquette, 1,929, Sweepings, 140.

div.head: MALTA INDEPENDENCE DAY.
div.p: To day being the anniversary of the libera- tion of Malta from the Turkish yoke (A.D. 1565) after a fierce siege of Valetta, the Malese Philharmonic Society "La Valetta" will hold a ball at its headquarters 83, Rue 1er Khedive, opposite Minet el Bassal Bourse. Maastro Pipito's string band will play.

The history of the Key of the Mediteranean is as choppy as the waves that roll along her shoreless ramparts. In fact it has been the dumping-ground of the nations who have held in turn the mastery of that sea. Thus it has been conquered successively by the Phoenicians, in the 13th century B.C., Greeks, 735 B.C., Carthage 400, B.C., Romans 218 B C., Vandals 454 A.D., Goths 464 A.D., Byzantines 523 A.D., Arabs 870-904, Normans 1090, Spaniards 1284, who joined it to Sicily. 1530 marked an epoch in the history of the devoted islet, for on that year Charles V. ceded it to the Knights of St. John of Jerusalem, who had been ousted from Rhodes ; and they it was who saved it from the Turks under Mustafa Pasha, the lieutenant of Suleiman the Magnificent.

They were destined to dispute with the Turks the dominion of the seas until 1798, when Bonaparte captured Valetta, holding it for two years, during which he was always being attacked by the English, who with the aid of the Maltese themselves, took it in 1800, the change of ownership being finally ratified in 1815.

div.head: COAL IMPORTS.
div.p: From 1st January to 6th September 1906 803,893 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, as against 688,224 last year.
This total was made up as follows:— Welsh, 422,580, Newcastle, 143,728, Scotch, 76,639, Yorkshire, 117,673, Other qualites, 43,273.

div.head: ABOUKIR.
div.p: Two additional trains are to run between Alexandria and Aboukir from the 10th inst. to the 15th proxo., leaving Alexandria at 9 p.m. and Aboukir at 10.30 p.m.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: To-night the grand symphonic concert in the theatre begins at 10 o'clock. To-morrow afternoon there will be a vocal and instrumental concert, and variety entertainment.

div.head:
UPPER EGYPT LINE.
WASTA TO MINIEH DOUBLING.
div.p: The important undertaking of doubling the line between Wasta and Minieh is making good progress, and it is hoped that 40 or 50 kilometres of double track will be put into service towards the end of this year. In addition to the doubling of the line, this work comprises the alteration and improvement of twenty stations. In regard to the expropriations, the land necessary for the new stations and plate-layers' huts only has been purchased, the existing railway property being in all cases sufficient for the line itself. The total area purchased in 1905 was 56 feddans, at an average price L.E. 113. or L.E. 6,328 in all.

204,100 cubic metres of earth-filling has been done in widening the bank for double track, and 490,200 cubic metres for alteration to stations. The total amount of earthwork was 694,300 cubic metres, of which 45% was transported by train, and the remainder obtained from borrow pits.

At Wasta Station all the building works have been completed, except three pits and the ironwork of the locomotive shed. At seventeen other stations the buildings have either been completed or are in hand. At Minieh one platform has been completed, as well as lodgings for the traffic, locomotive and permanent way staff. Foundatinns for the remaining buildings are in hand. 4.500 metres of track have been laid at this station, and 142,600 cubic metres of filling have been done. The amount expended under this head during 1905 was L.E. 97,597.

div.head: TRADE WITH THE SUDAN.
div.p: The Director of Customs in the Sudan, with a view to assisting merchants and intending traders, has issued the following statement :— "Merchants should be careful to see that if lighterage or landing charges are levied, they are included in the freight rate.
"All goods should be well packed, and the final destination marked in clear letters together with the port of discharge.

"Multiplicity of marks should be avoided ; most of the goods received from Egypt being packed in old cases, have three or four destinations marked on the packages, and wrong delivery is an almost constant complaint.

"Whisky, liquors, and provisions should be packed in screw-fastened, iron-bound cases, the increased cost of packing being amply justified by the decrease in breakages and pilferages. Sugar should also be packed in iron- bound cases ; the present cases are useless for camel transit, and do not stand ordinary handling.
"Bales of cotton should not exceed 500 kilos. in weight, and under no circumstances should bales over this size be shipped, unless specially ordered.
"The Customs being ad valorem, shippers must supply their clearers with invoices showing the cost of the goods, c.i.f. Sudan.
"Merchants are advised to send out their own representatives."
Among the items mostly required may be noted the following :-
Galvanized iron (water and oil) tanks find a ready sale, as also safes. Tanks could be utilised for packing purposes with advantage.
Brass water taps. - Good quality recommended, as at present imports are of very inferior manufacture.
Iron locks, keys, door knobs. —A very cheap and inferior quality of these articles is imported at present ; good British fittings would find a ready sale.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINES.
UM RUS.
div.p: Progress report for the half-month ended July 31 : —"Main shaft section : 650 ft. level cross-cut has progressed a farther 16 ft ; total, 40 ft. 550 ft. level main winze has been sunk 12 ft. ; total depth, 88 ft. ; winzes is now in black dyke No. 3 ; a sample of the vein at 87 ft., where the quartz was 15 ins., assayed 2 dwts. 14 grains. 450 ft. level north-east advanced 24 ft. ; total length, 416 ft. ; formation carries stringers 1 in. to 2 ins. wide, unsampled. 450 ft level south-west : branch drive in the footwall suspended at 414 ft.; at 400 ft. a diagonal cross cut was started, which holed winze 3 ; driving on the vein is now in progress ; a sample of the lode at 420 ft. assayed a trace over 12 ins. ; new main level driven 20 ft; total length, 420 ft. 450 ft level south-west: winze 1 sunk 18 ft to total depth of 70 ft ; the vein is 14 ins. wide, assaying 14 dwts. 17 grains ; the stope below 850 ft level sooth west assayed 9 dwts. 10 grains over 17 ins. ; the stope below 245 ft level south-west assayed 12 dwts. over 24 ins. ; two stopes over 245 ft level south-west assayed 1 oz. 6 dwts. 3 grains over 23 ins. Western shaft section ; Western shaft was sunk 23 ft. ; total depth, 500 ft ; the shaft has passed through dyke 12, is now in granite; but the vein is thrown upward. 270 ft level south-west driven 21 ft. ; total, 220 ft. ; vein 3 ins, assaying 1 dwt. 387 ft. level south-west advanced 28 ft. ; total length. 70 ft ; vein cut at 54 ft,, and has since averaged 9 ins. wide, assaying 10 dwts. 16 grains; drive now in dyke No. 13."

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Avocs, of the Westcott and Laurence Line of London, left Malta yesterday and is due here next Monday, the 10th inst., with general cargo from Antwerp and London.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: TINNED MEATS IN EGYPT.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette".

Sir,—With reference to the publication, by the Press of this country, upon the Neill-Reynolds report, on Chicago packing house conditions, all tending to create the belief that the large packers of this country are in the business of selling condemned and diseased meat to the public, those attacks, however unjust, must arrest if not destroy an important branch of the food trade at a time when life is getting dearer from day to day. The British public have taken the alleged exposures very much to heart, and it is the duty of the Press to restore public confidence in canned goods ; therefore we take the liberty in sending you a statement made by Chicago Packers, by the "Standard" represetative and by the "Tribune" correspondent, showing that the present outcry is grossly exaggerated.
Messrs. Armour and Company of Chicago, Kansas City, Omaha, St. Louis and of London, whom we represent, have authorized us to make the following positive statement on their behalf:

All beef, pork, mutton, or other food products, canned or otherwise, shipped from our packing houses are inspected in accordance with the Act of Congress, March 3rd, 1891, which provides—"that the Secretary of Agriculture shall cause to be made careful inspection of all live animals and the meat thereof intended for export, and that no steamer may clear from our ports carrying meat products until the certificates of the Department of Agriculture shall have been obtained and filed with the proper port authorities."

Furthermore, every carcass or part thereof found by the United States' Government Inspectors to be in any way diseased or unfit for food is condemned by and destroyed under the personal supervision of the U. S. Government's Inspectors.

We enclose farther a summary of the results of Government investigations of Chicago packing, showing that the foods issued by Messrs. Armour and Company are above reproach and that the public may consume the canned provisions coming from this establishment without the slightest shade of anxiety.

In view of all these circumstances, and of the fact that the prevalent abuse is largely the result of the example set by many of our leading newspapers, would it not be a worthy and honourable step on the part of your journal to check once for all these false statements.
This appeal to your sense of justice and honour is made in the interest of international goodwill, and we feel sure that it will not be made in vain.
We have the honour, to be
Yours Respectfully.
SAOULLI AND ROBERT.
Sole Agents for Armour & Company's Meats.
Alexandria, August 3.
To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette "

Sir,—Referring to the rather strange article signed "Sanitas" about tinned meats, which appeared in your issue of yesterday, we beg to point out that there is no truth whatever in the scandalous stories which have been published about the Chicago packing houses. "Sanitas" seems to have been led away by the "Yellow" journals, who care for nothing but the publication of something sensational, in order to increase their circulation.

We hold at the disposal of "Sanitas" the extract from the Report of the Committee of the U. S. Department of Agriculture, showing that the charges brought up by the "Jungle" are all false. This journal who talks lightly does not seem to realise that a violation entails on employer and employee a penalty of 12 months' imprisonment and a fine of 1000 dollars for each offence.
The Medical Magazine, edited by Mr. A. G. Auld, M.D., M.R.C.P, of London, writes as follows :—

" The presumption that the foods issued by Messrs. Armour & Company of Chicago etc., were objectionable is prima facie absurd, and now that we have incontrovertible proof that the most scrupulous care is taken, the public may consume the canned meats provisions coming from this firm without the slightest shade of anxiety. For our part we should say that it is much safer to eat canned meats which may contain a mere atom of foreign substances, than to partake of most of the stuff exposed for sale in butchers' shops."

The fact that 30 millions of tins of preserved food are consumed annually in the United Kingdom and that no well founded cases have been proved a danger to health is in itself an evidence during all these years that there could not been much dangerous food exported as some people may believe.
Facts are that President Roosevelt's investigations show Armours's Products to be above reproach. Armours' guarantee goes with every tin.
This, we hope, will enable you to remove all stories against American canned meats.
Very respectfully,
SOULLI & ROBERT.
Alexandria, August 7.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Muhamed Aly, who arrived at Alexandria on Thursday evening, attended midday prayers at Abou el-Abbas Mosque and then proceeded to Ras el-Tin Palace.
The life assurance of the late Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim amounted to one million francs not £1,000,000.
Mr. Langley, Inspector General of Upper Egypt Irrigation, has arrived here, and is staying two or three days at San Stefano Casino.
We regret to annonnce the death of Mme Raphael Suarès (née Marie Ruse Biot) who died at Villa Said, Paris, on the 23rd ulto., in her fifty sixth year.
Dr. Comanos Pasha is leaving Paris on the 19tb inst for Marseilles en route for Alexandria, where he will arrive on the 25th inst.
Captain J. C. Devenish, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusilier, has been granted leave of absence, in extension, to the 9th October.
Dr. J. Samad has arrived at Alexandria on his return from Chicago, and is proceeding shortly to the Lebanon to spend a few weeks at home.

The late G. O. C. in Egypt, the Hon. Sir Reginald Talbot, K.C.B., Governor of Victoria, has presented to the Corporation of Melbourne a pictore of the statesmen after whom the city, on its foundation in August, 1835, was named. William Lamb, second Viscount Melbourne, was at that time Prime Minister of England, and there is a painting of him by Partridge in the National Portrait Gallery. It is a copy of this, executed by Mr. Malcolm Stewart, that Sir Reginald Talbot has given to the Melbourne University.

div.head: INNISKILLING ADJUTANCY.
div.p: Lieutenant Lawrence E.G. Oates, who has just been appointed to the adjutancy of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, Cairo, is the gallant officer who, being in a tight corner during the late war, replied to the Boers, when called upon to surrender, that "the Inniskillings came to fight, not to surrender." He got his commision in the Inniskillings in May, 1900, from the 3rd Battalion West Yorkshire Regiment, then embodied, joined the regiment at the front afterwards, and saw a lot of service in the Transvaal. Orange River Colony and Cape Colony. He was severely wounded in the action referred to, his thigh being broken by a rifle bullet. His party retired in good order without the loss of a single rifle, and the brave officer was afterwards picked up by an ambulance. He was invalided home, and rejoined the regiment in the latter end of December, 1902, and served with it till the close of the war (mentioned in despatches. Queen's medal with five clasps).

div.head: THE COMING SEASON.
div.p: The tide of travel across the ocean during the winter months has turned from the Atlantic to the Mediterranean route, and the largest and fastest ocean grey-hounds will make trips to Egypt from America during the season. The White Star will run the Celtic and Cedric. The Canard will have the Carmania and Canonia ; the Deutschland will make a trip in February for the Hamburg-American Line, and the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse will represent the North German Lloyd.

div.head: A TUNISIAN PRECEDENT.
div.p: The French in Tunis make short work of the Arabic Press whenever fanatic or seditious articles are published. Recently a certain Abd-el Razak Ghattas published an article in a newspaper, which he had recently started, wherein he accused the Bey of being a simple instrument in the hands of the French, and also made a violent onslaught on the French management of the Protectorate. The Government intends dealing seriously with the case, and in all probability the newspaper will be suppressed. The articles in question were solely due to personal pique because the writer had been refused some favours he had asked the Government to grant.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit -within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: ELEMENTARY EDUCATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: To the Editor or the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—Although Egypt had for long been steeped in an ignorance which threatened to erase the reminiscences of her glorious past, yet circumstances have pitied our social situation by sending us reformers who after diagnosing our disease prescribed an efficacious remedy. They discovered that the main factor of this backwardness was the neglect of the education of lower class Egyptians, so that the contrast between the poor illiterates and the educated led to misunderstandings. They realised that the best means of avoiding such prevailing misapprehension was the education of that populace.

These reformers began, therefore, to devise ways and means, starting with the village Kuttabs scattered throughout the country. This task Government placed in the hands of the Ministry of Public Instruction, which drew up for the purpose a special scheme under the heading of the 'Kuttab Contribution.'
This scheme entitled the Fiki of a Kuttab, who is subject to the Ministry, to an annual subsidy.

Experiences and capable masters from the Arabic Training College were therefore selected to inspect the Kuttabs that were put under the care of the Ministry and to instruct the 'fikis' how to teach, organise, and manage. The inspectors did their duties so well that the number of Kuttabs subject to the Ministry's inspection began to rise gradually, amounting this year to 4,400 Kuttabs.

With the object of further improvement the Ministry decided that these village school masters should know something more than the Koran. They decided to give them private tuition on the afternoons of Thursdays and Fridays (the only leisure of Fikis) in all the Government schools and proper Kuttabs. Thanks to this measure Arabic (dictation, reading, composition and grammar), arithmetic (from digits to weights and measures) and Arabic penmanship are now thoroughly taught by the masters of the Government Schools in the different centres. An annual examination is held in the various centres. Successful candidates receive either Fiki or teacher's certificate for two-thirds of the total marks, or an "Arif" (pupil Fiki) Certificate for one third of the maximum marks.

In the examination this year more than 500 fikis and arifs were successful. Certificates entitle holder to employ in the organised kuttabs belonging to the Ministry, to a monthly salary, and to exemption from military service during such employ. The Ministry of Instruction feeling that the numbers of successful candidates graduated every year does not meet the requirements of the kuttabs, decided lately to establish day schools for masters and mistresses of kuttabs. A couple of years ago it founded the Abdel Aziz School at Cairo; last year one at Fayoum was opened, and one this year at Kalioub. It is, however, expected that in course of time more schools will be erected. The natives feeling the benefit of this scheme supported the Ministry with all their might. Almost every notable, singly or with the help of his fellow villagers built a new kuttab on plans made by the Inspector in the most hygienic spot. As a headmaster of a national school in Lower Egypt the writer visited many a recently built kuttab. Besides being well built they contain ample accommodation and the rooms are well aired. The idea which prevailed that the great cities of Egypt set an example of model kuttab building is wrong, for although satisfied with the education, training and discipline, the writer found sanitary conditions very indifferent. Indeed on more than one occasion, he mentioned the matter to the Alexandria kuttab Inspector. This at length had the desired effect and by order of the Municipality the walls were lime washed and sanitary inspectors paid frequent visits to these kuttabs and sent reports which paved the way for further reforms.

The daily reports given by the vernacular papers announcing the inauguration ceremonies of kuttabs in various localities, will, I believe support my idea and put me in such a position as to draw the attention of the Governor of Alexandria to the present deficiency in the kuttabs.- Yours truly,

div.head:
PALESTINE FOR THE JEWS
TURKEY'S REPORTED CHANGE OF ATTITUDE.
div.p: Prominent delegates at the Lesser Zionist congress now in session at Cologne consider it likely (the "Evening Standard" says) that Mr. Israel Zangwill, who at last year's congress headed the "Ito," a "Territorialist" section, which deserted the Zionist movement after riotous discussions, will before long again take stand beneath the Zionist banner.

The territorialists, it will be remembered, favoured the immediate acceptance and colonisation of the South African territory offered by the British Government rather than wait an indefinite period for the realisation of the Zionist dream of regaining Palestine itself.

Prominent Zionists, including Dr. Max Nordau and President David Wolfssohn, have stated at the present Congress that there is every probability of Turkey acceding within measurable time to the Zionist plea to be allowed to colonise Palestine.

The only obstacle in the way of the Zionist aspirations is the fact that Turkey, which has been compelled to face such an epidemic of problems of late, fears the growth of a supplementary Jewish question, and is therefore in a state of uncertainty as to what attitude to take towards the Zionist claim. President Wolfssohn states, however, that there is no semblance of truth in the assertion that the Jews once in possession of the territory, would work towards the establishment of a republic or a monarchy in Palestine.

"Theodore Herzl, the dead founder and leader of our movement," says President Wolfssohn, "might, by the aid of his powerful personality, have stood at the head of a Jewish monarchy but with his death Jewish monarchical government would have simultaneously come to an end."

The leaders of Zionism to-day agree that peaceable, free development under the suzerainty of Turkey is preferable to taking upon their shoulders all the huge responsibilities which the establishment of an independent government would involve.

div.head: Death of Lady Campbell-Bannerman.
div.p: The whole nation will feel the deepest sympathy with the Prime Minister in the cruel bereavement which he has sustained by the death of his wife, which took place yesterday afternoon at Marienbad. Party feeling is some times strong and occasionally even bitter in this country, but we are glad to think that it never impairs the kindly relations which exist between our public men, or the friendly interest which we all take in the domestic joys and sorrows of our statesmen. Nothing can greatly mitigate the severity of such a blow in the first days after it has fallen ; but such measure of solace as the assurance of the profound and genuine sympathy of all parties and all classes can bring him the Prime Minister will surely receive. ("Times.")

div.head: The Roosevelt Spelling Book.
div.p: A strong objection to the Roosevelt spelling scheme has not yet been noticed. That is, that it opens the door to a state of perpetual uncertainty and unrest in questions of orthography. The official list of 300 words is admittedly--even ludicrously—incomplete, and must be merely the first of many instalments. Suppose we have a new hatch of 300 words for every succecding American President. What is likely to be the state of mind of the average American citizen at the end of ten years? The position of the Englishman who has to keep himself abreast of a list of new titles every Birthday and New Year, so as not to confuse Lord St. Aldwyn with Lord Selby or Lord Knaresborough, is but a faint reflection of it. ("Tribune.")

div.head: Liberals and their Allies
div.p: Mr. Keir Hardie, after considerable experience of Liberalism and its aims, has found himself forced to disagree, in more than details, with the testimonial which the Liberal party wrote for itself, in the hope of saving its admirers trouble. Victory, like adversity, makes strange bed fellows, but who would have thought that the Labour members would have diagnosed the Liberal party so rapidly? No doubt we shall have some more kaleidoscopic pictures of Liberalism as seen through Labour spectacles, when the Trade Union Congress meets at Liverpool next week. ("Telegraph".)

div.head: The Truth about the "Holiday Feeling."
div.p: Despite the veneer, there is a good deal of the savage in us all. There are hundreds of thousands of people who don't know, but are constantly striving to get back to a more natural condition. You go a walk in the country, you go out shooting, you go to Switzerland and climb hills. You call it a holiday, but the cause of the enjoyment is that the real man—the primeval ancestor in you—is coming into his own, is feeling in a natural element —(Dr. Nansen, in "London Magazine.")

div.head: The Boulevards of Paris.
div.p: The boulevards were once to Paris what long hair was to Samson—its secret and strength. Paris, in telling its secret to the whole world, lost a large part of its intellectual camaraderie. The life of the boulevards was as kind of social intimacy carried on in public ; the cafés were clubs, and privilege was firmly established in them, even though every seat seemed to be public. But a generation has changed that. The intimacy, which was a strange mixture of Bohemianism, artistic fellowship, civic and professional rapport, and the need for a political debating ground, has been swallowed by the publicity (become trebly public) which once protected it. It is as though an old fashioned English inn had been turned into a brand-new, brawling, gaudy hotel with all the "latest improvements" for doing away with the zest and flavour of life. (J. B. Atkins in "Standard.")

div.head: A German Discovery.
div.p: The German editors who visited London in a body so unexpectedly confess that one of their favourite illusions has been destroyed. John Bull is not at all like the cynical and amorphous beast they had imagined him to be. He is bland and complimentary, can smile without showing his teeth, admits that Germany is one of the greatest countries in the world, and even promises to maintain free-trade for the sake of Germany.—("Age," Melbourne.)

div.head: Our Useful Americans.
div.p: Americans are putting up John Bull's big buildings, constructing his subways, marrying and financing his penniless peers, producing his art, and keeping his teeth in order.— ("Critic," New York.)

div.head: Ephemeral Literature.
div.p: Any one of the large London or American daily papers consumes each day fully ten acres of an average forest. Such paper does not last. The wood fibre out of which it is made is, unlike pure cellulose, acted upon by light and air, and water and the organisms of decay. This is bad, but not wholly bad, for most of the literature appearing on this paper is made as mechanically as the paper itself, and it is fitting it should be as ephemeral in fact as it is in nature. But sometimes Literature (with a capital "L") appears on this wooden foundation, and that is a tragedy. Had Mr. Pepys written his admirable Diary upon what we call "scribbling paper" we would today have no Mr Pepys.-("Harper's Magazine.")
The 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards, on arrival in Egypt, will be stationed at Cairo. The battalion is due at Alexandria about the 11th October.

The Military Police, both mounted and dismounted, are to be substantially reduced next year, it is understood. The squadron in Egypt, which consists of 120 men, will be reduced to about 60 mounted men. At home it is purposed to replace a large number of the Military Police by ordinary regimental police.
Capt. T.G. Dalby. King's Royal Rifle Corps, on returning to regimental duty from employment with the Egyptian Army, has been posted to the 3rd Battalion K.R.R.C, Aldershot.

Major A. M. Pirie, D.S.O., on retiring from the 31st Empress of India's Lancers at Hounslow, has been appointed to a squadron in the Middlesex (Duke of Cambridge's Hussars) Imperial Yeomenry. Major Pirie joined the 21st, then a hussar regiment, in the January, 1889 was adjutant 1897-98, promoted captain in 1899, major in 1903, and was attached to the Egyptian Army 1898-1904. He was adjutant of the 21st in Kitchener's short but brilliant campaign up the Nile in 1898, and was in the maiden charge of the 21st at Omdurman, on which occasion he was slightly wounded. For his services he received a well earned D.S.O., mention in despatches and the medal and Egyptian medal with clasp.

Major W. H. Plumer, second in command of the 1st Battalion Royal Irish Fusiliers, Dublin, has been selected for the command of the battalion when Colonel Hill, D.S.O., vacates it in the course of a fortnight, under the four years' rule.

Rumour hath it that a part of Mr. Haldane's disbandment scheme will be curtailed. The reduction of the field artillery has come in for more hostile comment than any other section of his ill advised proposed redactions.

The 1st Battalion Border Regiment is due to embark to morrow on the S.S. Soudan at Southampton for conveyance to Gibraltar, where the liner is due on the 4th prox. In addition to the 1st Border Regiment, the Soudan takes out sundry drafts for the Rock and South Africa. The 1st Battalion Border Regiment was last in Gibraltar.

The cruiser Gladiator left Portsmouth yesterday with a new crew for the third class cruiser Proserpine, which Commander Herbert W. James will re-commission at Port Said for another tour of service on the East Indies Station.

Brevet Colonel John Fowle will vacate the command of the 21st Lancers at Hounslow on the 6th September in conformity with the four years' rule. Colonel Fowle has been associated with with the 21st since January, 1881, when he received his lieutenancy in it. He got his troop in 1887, majority in 1898, and took up the command of the regiment on the 7th September, 1902, it being then stationed in Dublin. Colonel Fowle also did duty with the Provisional Regiment of Lancers which was quartered at Ballincollig for some time. His service in the field includes the Soudan War, 1884-85 (medal with clasps and bronze star) ; the Nile Expedition, 1898, the charge of the 21st at Omdurman (mentioned in despatches, 4th class Osmanieh, Egyptian medal with clasp), and the South African War, 1900-1, in which he shared in the operations in Orange Free State, the action of Paardeberg and Driefontien (Queen's medal with three clasps).

The vacant majority in the Buffs, caused by the promotion of Lieutenant Colonel G. V. Dauglish to the command of the 1st Battalion at Dover, has been filled by the promotion of Captain and Brevet Colonel E.G.T. Bainbridge to the substantive rank of major. Brevet Colonel Bainbridge, who has been latterly a company officer in the 2nd Battalion at Harrismith, Orange River Colony, received his first commission in 'The Bufts" in February 1888, was promoted captain in 1897, brevet major in 1898, brevet lieutenaut colonel in 1900, and brevet colonel last year. He has seen a good deal of staff service, was twice employed with the Egyptian Army and commanded the School of Mounted Infantry 1903-04. Whilst with the Khedive's army he went through the Dongola Expedition, 1896 (mentioned in despatches, Egyptian medal with clasp); the Nile Expedition, 1897 (clasp), the Nile Expedition, 1898, including the battle of Khartoum (mentioned twice in despatches, brevet majority, medal, clasp) and in the South African War, 1899-1900, he commanded a battalion of Mounted Infantry will great success, covering the operations in Orange Free State, the actions of Paardeberg, Poplar Grove, Houtnek, and Zand River ; operations in the Transvaal, actions of Johannesburg, Pretoria, Diamond Hill ; operations in Orange River Colony, the actions of Wittebergen, Ladybrand, & co., (mentioned in despatches, brevet lieutenant colonelcy, Queen's medal with five clasps). Recently he was senior officer at Harrismith in virtue of his army rank, although only regimentally a captain of the Buffs.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres vient de remonter de 1/8 à 3 1/2 pour cent. Hier, an Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a perdu non moins de 1/4 de livre à 86 3/4. L'Unifiés est restée invariés à 104 1/2. La National Bink a clôturé avec un quart de baisse à 27. L'Agricole a regagné 1/8 à 9 7/8. La Daïra a reperdu 1/8 à 16 3/4. La Delta Light s'est tenue à 11 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien est demeurée inchangée à 762, de même que la Banque d'Athènes à 143.

Nous avons en, ce matin, un marché relative- ment calme, avec des transactions assez restreintes. La sente particularisé à noter est que divers titras dont les cours avaient été poussés hier ont reperdu une partie de leur avance.

La National Bank a été ramenée à 26 11/16 et l'Agricole à 9 3/4-13/16. Le Crédit Foncier s'est maintenu à 760-761 ; les obligations à lots anciennes ont été traitées à 338 339. La Béhéra s'est alourdie à 36. La Nile Land s'est raf- fermie à 13 7/8.14 et l'Union Foncière à 6 1/8.
L'action Immobilière a rétrogradé à 387-338. Les Improvements ont perdu 3/16 à il S, ven- deurs.
L'action Enterprise and Development a avancé h 12 5/16 et la part de fondateur à 20 3/4-21. La part de fondateur Warden Estate a reculé à 8 1/2 et les Automobiles à 5 3/8-7/16.
En bonne tendance, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont clôturé à 269.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont été mieux tenus à 17 1/4-5/16 Les Egyptian ont molli à 6 3/8.
Parmi les petites valeuts, les Delta Land se sont maintenus à 3 7/16-1/2 et les Sait and Soda entre 21 sh. 3 et 11 sh. 6.

Suivant des renseignements qu'on nous transmet d'Alexandrie, voici la nomenclature des propriétés que l'Egyptian Trust and Invest- ment Ltd. (Glymenopoulo) cède à la Building Lands of Egypt Co. par suite de la fusion:

1˚— 600,000 pics "Terrains Diamanti," près Khedivah Palace à Ramleh. vis à vis le V c toria School ; prix d'achat P.E. 12, valant actue'lement P.E. 30 en bloc. Les 30,000 pics achetés dernièrement par Moukhtar pacha sont voisins de cette propriété ; ils avaient appartenu à la Building,mais le Trust possédait, également uns participation.
2˚— 30,000 pics à P.E. 30. situés du côté de la mer et donnant sur la route carrossable qui conduit à Khedivah-Palace.
3˚— 55,000 pics situés à Dahrieh, là où l'on compte édifier la Cité ouvrière ; ils out coûté P.E. 12.
4˚—' 50,000 pics à Bulkeley, au prix de P.E. 21.
5˚— 50,000 pics de terrains lotis à Abou- Nawatir, à P.E. 33. Les transactions dans ce quartier se font couramment entre P.E. 60 et 80 le pic.
6˚-— 4,500 pics (en participation) à Minet- el-Bassal à P.E. 100, comprenant une vaste chounah.
7˚—4,500 pics des "Ecuries Valerzia," au quartier grec, entre la rue Rosette et le Boule- vard d'Allemague, rapportant le 10% sur le prix d'achat de 4 livres le pic.
Le Trust apporte, en outre, 10,000 actions privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie coûtant Frs. 157, lesquelles lui servent à s'assurer la majorité dans les décisions de la Société.
Enfin le Trust, disposerait d'une somme liquide de £70,000, dont une partie pro- viendrait de bénéfices réalisés sir la revente de terrains.
Tous comptes , on estimerait la plus vaine de l'actif du Trust à £175,000 environ, sauf errent ou ommission.
En attendant, l'action Building Lands a été ramenée hier à £5 à la Bourse d'Alexandrie; les Glynenopoulo ont clôturé à 1 7/16 ache- teurs.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Londre, en date du 31 août, les lignes suivantes :

"La perspective de prochaines demandes d'argent porte notre marché monétaire à la circonspection. C'est ainsi que le taox de l'es- compte libre est plutôt ferme à 3 3/8 et qu'il pourrait bientôt remonter à 3 1/2. La Banque d'Angleterre continue à renforcer sa position dont la faiblésse avait tant inquiété notre place pendant le premier semestre de l'année. Elle a, d'ailleurs, réussi à relever sa réserve au-delà du niveau où elle se tensit l'année dernière à cette époque. C'est rassurant, carnous voiciarrivés au moment où les besoins de capitaux qu'amène l'autom e commencent à se faire sentir en Amérique ; ils pourraient, cette année, être d'autant plus intenses que les prix des céréales et du coton sont relativement faibles."

Un avis de MM. Norton, Rose, Barrington and Co., 57 1/2 Old Broad Street à Londres, sollicitors de la liquidation de la Daira Sanieh Sugar Corporation Ltd., avis en date du 31 août dernier, publié daus le 'Journal Officiel" d'avant hier, invite les créanciers de la dite Société a adresser, avant la 1er Octobre pro- chain, leurs demnndes en règle à M. W. B. Peat, liquidateur de la Compagnie, 11, Iron- monger Lane, E.C., à Londres.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier DE
"L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l'"Egyptian Gazette" parsit chaque Samedi à midi, de facon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartisles du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les der- nières statisques jusqu'à la veille de sa publi- cation: des tableaux des fluctuations de la dlace et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc.
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: Cotons
div.p: Nous allons encore une fois parler de la vieille récolte, mais que nos lecteurs ne s'effra- yent pas, car pour aujourd'hui il se s'agit que de deux mots sur la relevé statistique de fin d'année, que nous reproduisons plus loin, et sur lequel nous attirons leur attention.

Eu définitive la récolte n'a été que de cant. 5,950,000 environ, mais elle a amplement suffi au point de nous laisser un arriété assez im- portant et dépassant les prévisions les plus pessimistes. En effet, et dès que les consé- quences de la campagne insensée à la hausse, qui avait porté les cours à 23 tallaris, avaient commencé à se faite sentir, on a estimé que l'arriéré à fin Août serait d'environ 150,000 cantars, ét c'est avec cantars 220,400 que nous terminons la campagne. Et qu'on dise après cela que la filature ne peut pas se défendre quand elle est surprise an milieu de la saison! Mais tiéve de réflexions sur ce sujet et pas- sons à la revue du marché. Elle sera relative- ment courte cette fois, car l'espace nous est mesuré, mais elle aura l'avantage d'ennuyer un peu moins le lecteur.

Le début de la semaine n'a rien eu de bril- lant, la première séance s'étant terminée en baisse de 1/8, après que les cours avaient reculé de 1/4 de tallari, mais cette faiblesse n'a été que passagère, car la matinée de lundi nous a valu le retour au der- nier. Ce jour ls les achats du Commerce d'ex- portation ont été tellement importants qu'ils ont fini par faire changer d'allure au marché. Mardi il y a en de noaveau calme et baisse, mais arrivés au minimum de 15 15/16, il y a eu reprise et depuis lors nous n'avons fait que progresser jusqu'à clôturer aujourd'hui à 16 15/32 acheteurs.

Les velléités de vendre, ne fût ce que pont écraser les cours, ne mat quent pas au décou- vert, mais de leur côté les achats de l'expor- tation ont fini par impressionner ru mettre un frein aux baissiers. Et de fait, il y a de quoi s'arrêter, car la filature ne fait qu'acheter et maintenant c'est l'Angleterre à son tour qui commence à bouger. Nos exportateurs ne man- quent pas d'ordres de tous les côtés, et la compagne 1906-7 a l'air de vouloir Dons réser- ver des surprises au point de vue de la con- sommation. Certains filateurs se sont déjà assurés de la marchandise pour livraison jus- qu'en Septembre 1S07 et d'autres auraient voulu même opérer jusqu'a Janvier 1908, mais Alexandrie n'a pa pu les suivre à ce point, surtout que sur la question du prix il n'y a pas eu possibilité d'accord. En tous cas, nos maisons de commerce ne cachent nullement l'importance de leurs engagements et de tout ce que l'on entend, il ressort que la position du vendeur en blanc pourrait ne pas être enviable à un moment donné. les positions à découvert sont formidables et si les intéressés ne prennent pas leurs précautions pour les réduire maintenant qu'il en est temps encore, ilscourent la risque de se voir débordés.

Certes toute la révolte n'est pas encore placés en Europe et no cultivateurs conti- nuent à se montrer vendeurs aux cours ac- tuels, mais de la façon dent les choses vont ou semblent vouloir allen nous pourrions bien nous réveiller un dos ces jours avec notrené cote aux trois quarts vendue.

L'Amérique ne fait que tourner autour des cours de vendredi dernier, et il semble que tout le monde est hésitant et reste dans l'attente du Rapport du Bureau d'Agriculture qui devait paraltre ce soir, mais qu'on dit maintenant ne devoir être publié que lundi prochain. Au fond il ne nous dira rien que cous ne sachions déjà, mais ceux qui croient à la baisse à cause des pronostics de 79 à 80 pourraient bien se tromper Il est incontesta- ble que dans ces conditions, l'état de la plante serait des plus satisfaisants, mais la récolte est elle déjà assurée? Et puis le ni- veau actuel des prix n'escompte-t-il pas beau- coup de choses?

Chez nous aussi la récolte marche à mer- veille et le résumé d'août de la Produce Asso- ciation, que nous reproduisons plus loin, nous le confirme, mais avec touut cela on ne saurait rien affirmer encore. Si la première cueillette est hors de danger, la deuxième est encore exposée aux risques des brouillards et la troi- sième aurait besoin d'une continuation de la température chaude ; c'est du reste pour cette raison que le Comité a cru devoir modérer sensiblement la note enthousiaste des corres- pondants de l'intérieur de l'Association.

Le marché du disponible n'a eu aucune im- portance. En cotons ancienne récolte on ne fait rien et en cotons nouveax il n'y a pas d'arrivages suffisants pour bien alimenter les affaires. Dans tous les cas, et malgré la baisse de 1/2 tallari sur les provenances Haute- Egypte que signale le Bulletin de ce jour, ces qualités sont recherchées.

Les autres genre de coton ne sont plus cotés faute de marchandise et faute de transactions pour pouvoir en constater la valeur réelle. On a vendu aussi hier du Fayoumi, pas trop beau, à 16 3/4 et anjourd'hui un lot de Ghizah à 19 1/4.

Les exportations ont été mauvaises. le total de la semaine étant de balles 1,1OO, contre balles 4500 en 1905, mais avec les cotons vieux mis à l'index par la filature, il faudra forcément attendre le développement des arri- vages pour voir les expéditions au dehors pren- dre un peu plus d'importance.

Liverpool a montré de meilleures disposi- tions pour les égyptiens disponibles, sous le rapport des ventes, bien entendu, car pour ce qui est des prix c'est encore la baisse que nous avons à signaler. Le disponible, qui était à 10 pence, il y a huit jours, est tombé à 9 11/l6, tandis que les futurs finissent à 8 61/61 pour le Septembre et à 8 15/64 pour le Novembre.

Les Américains disponibles ont été un peu plus actis aussi, mais ils ont joui d'une petite amélioration dans la cote, le spot ayant clôturé aujourd'hui à 545, soit 4 points de hausse, tandis que l'octobre novembre gagne 4 points à 4.97 et la Janvier - Février 5 points au niveau de 5.01.

PS—Nous donnous plus loin les chiffres du Ministère des Finances de la superficie plantée en coton, mais pour notre part nous n'y atta- chons aucune valeur. — La Haute Egypte, malgré la réduction de 60,000 feddans donnera one récolte bien supérieure à celle de l'année dernière, qui a été un véritable désastre, tandis que le total général de 1,500,000 fed. laisserait supposer on rendement cultural de 4 1/8 Cantars par feddan en moyenne pour toute l'Egypte. Cela est inadmissible et c'est à peu près à 2,000,000 de feddans qu'il faudrait estimer la superficie réelle.

div.head: Graines de Coton:
div.p: Comme pour le coton, nous renvoyons nos lecteurs au résumé du mouvement de la cam- pagne que nous reproduisons plus loin. Nous sourions bien voulu analyser les chiffres et en faire la comparaison avec nos précédentes indications de Mars dernier, mais nous faisant défaut nous reviendrons sur la matière Vendredi prochain.

En attendant, nous constatons que le stok à fin de campagne eat à peu près nul, était donné que sur les 104,500 Ardebs il y a lieu de déduire Ard. 25,000,embarquements de otte semaine, Ard. 25,000 environ appartenant, à nos huileries et qui ne sont pas destins à la vente et enfin Ardebs 35,000 rep les engagements en voie d'exécutionn on à exé- cuter à bref délai. Les véritables disponbilités de place pour les nouvelles affaires sraient donc d'Ard. 20,000 en tout, ce qui n'et pas lourd.

Heurensement, que les nouveaux arrivages commencent et que les besoins de hull ne paraissent pas si impérieux pour le moment. Eu tous cas, comme force de position satisti- que de l'article, les chiffres ci-dessus parlent d'eux-mêmes.
Le marché du disponible est très ferme et le prix de la nouvelle graine Haute-Egypte a fini ce matin à 68 3/4.
Pour Septembre on a parlé de 69 et la ce- mande semble assez bonne.

En contrats, il y a pen d'affaires. Au con- menesment, nous avons eu la baisse, mais ce- puis deux jours, il y a eu quelques achats pour compte de l'exportation et les prix sont reman- tés pour finir avec 1 Piastre de hausse sur le plus bas cours pratiqué. Cote actuelle de 3 mois P.T. 63.
Hull se montre réservée, mais ses cours ont fermes à £ 6.12/6 pour Septembre et £ 6.2 à 6.3/9 pour les 3 mois. Le demande de ce cité- là ne peut guère tarder à se réveiller.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Peut être dans le courant du mois prochain aurons nous un commencement d'animation, di ions nous dans notre dernière obtonique Cette prévision s'est réalisée cette semaine mêne: il y a en des affaires en assoz grand nombre avec un rleèvement des cours pluss ou moins sensible. Qu'il nous suffise de signaler une hausse de 7/16 sur la National Bank, de 1/16 sur l'Agricole, de 5/16 sur la Ramleh Railway, de 1 shelling 3 pence sur la Salt & Soda, de 1/8 sur la Delta Land, de 8/12 sur la Land Bank, de 1/8 sur l'Urbaine et de 1 £ sur la part de fondateur Comptoir.

A Londres les valeurs égyptiennes témoi- gnent aussi d'une plus-value, excepté la Daira. La National Bank gagne 5/8 à 27, l'Agricole et la Delta Light 1/8 respectivement à 9 7/8 et 11 3/4. Il en est de même à Paris où tons nos titres avancent de quelques pointe, malgré la baisse de la rente française et du Consolidé anglais. Quant au taux privé d'escompte, après une réduction momentanée de 1/8, il clôture au même niveau de 3 1/2.

Le grand évènement de la semaine a été sans contredit l'absorption du Trust par la Building Lands of Egypt, votée définitivement à l'assemblée générale extraordinaire du 4 courant. En raison de cette fusion il sera créé 60,000 nonvelles actions Building Lands de £4 qui seront échangées à leur valeur nomi- sale conte les 200,000 actions du Trust, soit 3 Building Lands contre 10 Trust. Le prési- dent de l'assemblés a fait ressortit la situation exceptionnellement bonne du Trust dont les propriétés auraient une superficie totale de près de 3/4 de million de pics, situés dans les environs les plus prospères de la ville. Quoi- qu'il en soit, en bourse la Building Lands a baissé de 3/32 pendant que le Trust demeure très soutenu à 1 7/16scheteurs.

Il ressort d'une étude sur les Splendid Hotels que le premier exercice n'a pas répondu aux espérances des actionnaires. Soit mau- vais administration, soit aussi fermeture du New Khedivial Hotel durant les agrandisse- mets, les berneraices nets n'ont été que de £1,500. bien que les recettes aient atteint £22,000. Henreusement, l'exercice courant se présente sous de bien meilleurs auspices. Un directeur de la plus haute compétence, M. Reinsperger, a été engagé sur la désignation même de M. Baehler. La situation des Splendid est d'ailleurs loin d'être mauvaise. Les 6,000 pics de terrain et l'immeuble du New Khedi- vial Hotel ont coûté ¡a le société L.E. 63,000, et les agrandissements environ L.E. 12,000; co qui fait un prix global de L.E. 75,000. Or la valeur actuelle de cette propriété dépasse certainement £90,000, montant de tout le capi- tal social.

Une société, d'un genre tout nouveau pour l'Egypte, a été enregistrée le 29 août à Londres sous le nom de "Caffari's Cooperatice Mar- kets." Les clients de cette coopérative auront leur part de bénéfice tout comme les action- naires. M. Caffari, administrateur-délégué, est attendu au Caire le 14 courant, de retour d'une inspection des principaux établissements similaires d'Europe, fonctionnant à Londres, Milan, etc.

Un versement de 62 fr. 50 est appelé sur les actions du Crédit Foncier Egyptien. La date de ce versement expirait hier. Les dites actions ne sont donc plus négociables qu'en titres libérés de 187 fr. 50. En liquidation du 15 sep= membre, les négociations s'effectueront exclu- vivement en titres libérés du dit versement.

Une répartition de £ 2. 10 sh. par action ordinaire de la Daira Sugar Corporation est payable depuis le 3 septembre à la banque Glyn, Mills, Currie et Co, 67, Lombard Street, E.C., contre remise des certificats d'actions qu porteur.

On se rappelle que la Commercial Industrial and Land Company of Egypt, fondée récem- ment, avait pour objet l'absorption (par voie d'options) de cinq sociétés, à savoir: R. Kuster & Co, Ed. Kirby & Co, Murdoch and Temple- ton, Mansourah Electric Light Concession, terrain à bâtir dans l'ile de Rodah. Or parmi toutes ces options, la Commercial Industrial and Land Company n'a donné suite qu'à celle de R. Kuster & Co, l'une des meilleures firmes d'Egypte.

Habib Bey Ghanem et Selim Bey Shakir, q'on dit délégués par l'Enterprise and Develop- ment Co pour traiter avec Ibrahim Tabet Bey l'achat de son vaste domaine d'usai, dont la superficie n'est pas inférieure à 3 millions de mètres carrés, ont obtenu de lui une option que la société devra rectifier d'ici au 15 octo- bref, dernier délai. Les conditions du marché seraient avantageuses pour les deux contrac- tants.

Les recettes actuelles de la Menzaleh Canal Company sont en moyenne de £5 par jour, entre marchandises et passagers, c'est-à-dire qu'elles cont loin de couvrir les frais de navi- gation. Tant que le canal ne sera pas creusé jusqu'à Port Said, le transport du coton ne rapportera rien, car il faut le décharger à Karputi et le recharger sur wagons pour le transporter à Port Said. La prolongation du canal jusqu'a Damiette et sa mise en com- munication avec le Nil ne sont pas moins nécessaires pour faire rendre à l'entreprise un dividende. De plus, pour attirer les voya- leurs, il y aurait lieu de construire un bô el à Matarieh et d'approfondir le canal, car actuel- lament on touche fréquemment la vase et des pants de s b'e. La correspondant qui nous adresse ceci formations, estime que, ces amé- rations une fois réalisées, l'entreprise pourra dunuer de bons bénéfices.

Les bruits les plus divers ont couru sur a démission de M.C. Meimarachi. La vérité est que cette démission n'a pas été donnée. M. C. Meimarachi est actuellement à Paris et ne se rendra à Londres que vers le milieu du mois pour assister à la réunion du con- soil et lui soumettre son rapport sur l'exer- cise écoulé, ainsi que son projet de construc- tion de nouveaux magasins au Caire. Dans le cas où le conseil rejetterait le projet de M. Meimarachi, celui ci est décidé à donner sa démission. Mais il faut espérer que ce projet sera adopté, car, dans le cas contraire, une assemblée générale des actionnaires sera con- voquée en Egypte où se trouvent les sept huitièmes des actions de la Cie Walker and Meimarachi et comme la plupart des porteurs sont des amis de M. C. Meimarachi, il pourrait bien se faire qu'ils demandent la suppres- sion du consil de Loudres. Ce conseil qui coûte à la société £2000 par an n'a aucune raison d'être ; sa place est au contraire toute indiquée au Caire.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION.

p.hi: Résumé des réponses recues en Août 1906.

div.p: Les conditions atmosphériques ont été favo- rables pendant ce mois et les cotonniers en ont profité.
Nos correspondants sont unanimes à con- stater l'innocuité des brouillards signalés les derniers jours du mois, et à ne parler des vers qu'à titre de mémoire.
Le Nil, dont la crue est abondante, a facilité les arrosages et permis de supprimer le régime des rotations.
Tout a donc bien marché jusqu'à présent et si cette situation se prolonge, on peut espérer que la récolte sera bonne.

Dans la Basse-Egypte, il y a des districts où la première cueillette sera en avance sur celle de l'année dénière et deviendra dans la se- condé quinzaine de Septembre; dans la Haute- Egypte, elle a commencé.

Nous sommes redevables à l'extrême obli- geance de S.E. le Ministre des Finances du tableau que nous transcrivons ci-contre et qui indique le nombre de fendants occupés cette année, par les différentes variétés de coton que cultive l'Egypte, Province par Province. En regard nous avons noté les mêmes indications pour 1905.
Alexaudrie, le 31 Août 1906.
